poem:
Title: The Unwritten Checks of Life

Once lovers, now debts binding unseen,
In a house that still echoes disrespect, cruel and mean.
Barclays, the monolith, cold and unmoved,
Her shattered dreams grotesquely unmortgaged, disapproved.
And tepid ombudman's orders, a thin veneer,
Facing the monsoon of misery, who dares to steer?
Two daughters, flood survivors, in life's raging tide -
The struggle their compass, hope their unsinkable guide.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I was abused twice, first by my partner and then by my bank’ A woman whose controlling partner’s abrupt departure left her with an unaffordable mortgage has accused Barclays of refusing to help her as she struggled with the fallout. Sally James*, a mother of two teenage daughters, says the bank refused to restructure her repayments when she could no longer afford them after being left as a single parent. And when the ombudsman ordered Barclays". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
